code-runner.executorMap.dockerfile: cd $dir && docker build -t my-image . && docker run my-image

[typescript].editor.fontFamily: 'Fira Code', 'FiraCode Nerd Font', 'VictorMono Nerd Font', 'Fira Code iScript', 'Fira Code', 'Fira Code iScript','Fira Code iScript'

[javascript].editor.fontFamily: 'VictorMono Nerd Font', 'Fira Code iScript', 'Fira Code', 'Fira Code iScript','Fira Code iScript'

editor.fontFamily: 'FiraCode Nerd Font', 'VictorMono Nerd Font Mono', 'Fira Code', 'Fira Code iScript','Fira Code iScript'
markdown.preview.fontFamily: 'Ubuntu', 'Droid Sans', -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe WPC', 'Segoe UI', system-ui, 'Ubuntu', sans-serif
chat.editor.fontFamily: 'VictorMono Nerd Font', 'Source Code Pro Black', 'MesloLGS Nerd Font', 'TerminessTTF Nerd Font', 'ProFontIIx Nerd Font', 'Source Code Pro Black'

github.copilot.chat.codeGeneration.instr.text: Separate domain logic and infrastructure in all project structures.
Ensure strict modularity in every code component, keeping logic, data, and I/O separated.
Organize projects into logical modules with minimal interdependencies.
Encapsulate infrastructure concerns in dedicated layers to protect domain logic.
Use interfaces or abstract classes to define boundaries between components.
Use dependency injection or abstract factory patterns for service instantiation.
Design repositories to be interchangeable with minimal impact on the domain layer.
Separate command operations from queries, following CQRS principles.
Always refactor large functions into smaller units of work that perform a single responsibility.
Enable 'strict' mode in TypeScript projects with explicit typings for variables and functions.
Use named exports instead of default exports unless necessary for compatibility.
Avoid `import *` or `export *`; explicitly name all imports and exports.
Declare functions with named function declarations; avoid top-level arrow functions for declarations.
Never use the `as` keyword for type assertions in TypeScript.
Use consistent naming: folders in `kebab-case`, files in PascalCase or camelCase matching exports.
Use single quotes for JavaScript/TypeScript and semicolons to terminate all statements.
Include the filename and relative path as a comment at the top of code blocks in documentation.
Mock dependencies in TypeScript to simulate missing implementations for modular development.
Write unit tests for each module or function to ensure correctness before integration.
Use integration tests to validate how modules interact at a system level.
Ensure test coverage remains high (90%+), emphasizing automation during code changes.
Use defensive programming to validate inputs early, especially in public APIs or services.
Validate inputs and outputs with guards or utility functions.
Use functional programming principles to compose reusable, stateless functions.
Prioritize immutability, avoiding variable or object mutation; return new instances.
Leverage constructs like map, filter, and reduce for operations on collections.
Use declarative code to define what the code should do, not how it should do it.
Implement error-handling mechanisms that prevent unchecked error propagation.
Use asynchronous operations for long-running tasks to improve responsiveness.
Use `pnpm` exclusively for JavaScript/TypeScript (outside 'monorepo-one'); avoid `npm` or `yarn`.
Install packages in 'monorepo-one' using `rush add -m -p <package-name> [--dev].`
Use `rush update --make-consistent` in 'monorepo-one' to ensure consistent dependencies.
Use the `node:` prefix exclusively for Node.js core module imports.
Separate domain logic from infrastructure in all project structures.
Ensure strict modularity in every code component, keeping logic, data, and I/O separated.
Organize projects into logical modules with minimal interdependencies.
Encapsulate infrastructure concerns in dedicated layers to protect domain logic.
Use interfaces or abstract classes to define boundaries between components.
Use dependency injection or abstract factory patterns for service instantiation.
Design repositories to be interchangeable with minimal impact on the domain layer.
Separate command operations from queries, following CQRS principles.
Always refactor large functions into smaller units of work that perform a single responsibility.
Enable 'strict' mode in TypeScript projects with explicit typings for variables and functions.
Use named exports instead of default exports unless necessary for compatibility.
Avoid `import *` or `export *`; explicitly name all imports and exports.
Declare functions with named function declarations; avoid top-level arrow functions for declarations.
Never use the `as` keyword for type assertions in TypeScript.
Use consistent naming: folders in `kebab-case`, files in PascalCase or camelCase matching exports.
Use single quotes for JavaScript/TypeScript and semicolons to terminate all statements.
Include the filename and relative path as a comment at the top of code blocks in documentation.
Mock dependencies in TypeScript to simulate missing implementations for modular development.
Write unit tests for each module or function to ensure correctness before integration.
Use integration tests to validate how modules interact at a system level.
Ensure test coverage remains high (90%+), emphasizing automation during code changes.
Use defensive programming to validate inputs early, especially in public APIs or services.
Validate inputs and outputs with guards or utility functions.
Use functional programming principles to compose reusable, stateless functions.
Prioritize immutability, avoiding variable or object mutation; return new instances.
Leverage constructs like map, filter, and reduce for operations on collections.
Use declarative code to define what the code should do, not how it should do it.
Implement error-handling mechanisms that prevent unchecked error propagation.
Use asynchronous operations for long-running tasks to improve responsiveness.
Use `pnpm` exclusively for JavaScript/TypeScript (outside 'monorepo-one'); avoid `npm` or `yarn`.
Install packages in 'monorepo-one' using `rush add -m -p <package-name> [--dev].
Use `rush update --make-consistent` in 'monorepo-one' to ensure consistent dependencies.
Use the `node:` prefix exclusively for Node.js core module imports.
Use the following tags in all TypeScript projects to annotate and organize code effectively:
// TODO: Marks incomplete tasks or features. Always include the next steps or implementation plan.
// FIXME: Flags broken or suboptimal code. Provide context and potential solutions.
// BUG: Identifies known issues. Briefly describe the problem and include references to relevant tickets or issues.
// SECTION: Divides code into logical blocks. Add a short description of each block's purpose.
// LOG: Marks debugging or monitoring points. Include what is being logged and why.
// WARNING: Highlights risky or unsafe code. Explain why caution is needed and suggest safer alternatives.
// ERROR: Flags critical or unrecoverable issues. Provide debugging details and any possible recovery steps.
// UNIMPLEMENTED: Notes placeholders for missing code. Include the intended functionality or design plan.
// SIDE EFFECTS: Describes external impacts of code (e.g., global state modification). Always explain the effect.
// REVIEW NEEDED: Indicates sections that need peer review. Mention what aspects require feedback.
// INFO: Adds context or background for complex code. Provide enough detail for others to understand its purpose.
// HINT: Shares tips or optimizations. Suggest improvements or better practices.
